reviews.advice: Learn how to do your job
reviews.cons:
It was getting tough to get hours. 
The only feedback I received for staff was from reports.
The only feedback from students was usually a number. Students that didn't give a 1 or a 2 rarely let you know why they were unhappy.
When you ask for help they tell you to listen to recordings. 
Classes never become available the same time each week and if you don't reserve them yourself you just get the scraps.
And the students are mostly in classes beyond there level and are being passed by the high rated teachers.
reviews.pros:
Flexible hours when classes are available. 
When I started there was no cap on hours and they paid a Christmas bonus. Now they only send you messages to tell you you're not getting paid for something.

reviews.advice: Management really needs to increase communications between sales offices and the schools. Students often are sold something in home countries that we can't follow up on here at the local office.
reviews.cons: That said, the cooperate culture is lacking. Standards and regulations from higher up in management aren't enforced or don't apply in local offices. Cooperate management feels very distant and ineffective.
reviews.pros: The office culture (here in Miami Beach) is great. Friendly staff, all very good team players, everyone enjoys a good laugh. Most have international experience or knowledge, or are at least interested in traveling. Everyone brings good stories to the table.

reviews.advice:
commit to diversity and inclusion and don't just say you're committed. It starts with getting more people of color at the highest positions. All the product presidents and ceo are white and this leads to a very white culture. I literally heard a senior manager say "if someone doesn't like it here, they should just leave"

Paying tour consultants and other employees more would be a good step towards developing a more diverse workforce. The only people willing to work for these wages are typically people with generational wealth (white new englanders).
reviews.cons:
-below market pay
-no room for career growth unless you fit into the white rich new england culture
-everyone feels replaceable 
-management doesn't truly care about new employees' welfare and happiness
-youre treated like a cog in a machine

employerResponses.response: Thank you for sharing this feedback. We are committed to building the diversity of our workforce and ensuring that all employees feel a sense of belonging at EF.  In terms of salary, we regularly review our compensation package  to ensure we are competitive in the market - this includes our fantastic benefits package. I'd be happy to chat more. Feel free to reach out to me at emily.burke@ef.com. Thank you!

reviews.advice: Pay your staff better, don't put up with staff being rude to others, create more positions and levels so staff can move up within the company.
reviews.cons: Low salary, hard to achieve bonuses, teammates can treat you like crap and nothing is done about it, rare chance of advancement, stuck in a sales role for at least 3 years, cold-calling all the time.
reviews.pros: EF loves to have company parties and give out free swag. Young environment. Free International travel if you last a year. Great 2 week training program, laid back environment, no strict dress code, easy to speak with senior level management.

reviews.cons: Limited opportunities for growth in some departments, long hours often required so work life balance can sometimes be challenging
reviews.pros:
- Strong mission of breaking down barriers 
- EF has a great entrepreneurial spirit and values innovative ideas
- They offer opportunities to travel internationally for work
- You can really have an impact on the future of the product you work for
- Outstanding, motivated people at all levels of the organization
- Great open office environment (no dark basement or cubicles)
- Comprehensive benefits including very generous vacation time & holidays
reviews.summary: Great culture, outstanding people, constant innovation, amazing opportunities to travel the world- a perfect combination

reviews.advice: Meet with current staff to get insight on needs/wants of employees to help with retention. I feel like management doesn't listen enough and this leads to frustration from staff.
reviews.cons: Not enough focus on career growth, management isn't tuned in enough to the mass of employees, compensation is extremely poor considering the city of the main office is one of the most expensive places to live in the US, Needs more of a focus on what employees are saying, high turnover rate.
reviews.pros: Fun work environment, The people, Great travel opportunities, good benefits, bar in the building, great parties.
reviews.summary: Fun first job out of college!

reviews.advice: Be more transparent during the interview process about the responsibilities of the role and what is expected. Pay more and stop trying to keep everyone happy with alcohol. In terms of Directors, hire people who actually have experience and aren't just well liked.
reviews.cons: Pay is low, work load is high. Depending on the time of the year, people are exhausted and management expects you to work 50+ a week. Management tends to be very young and inexperienced. The company talks a lot about professional development and building you as a employee but the management used scare techniques to get you to perform better. They are not transparent during the interview process about what you will actually be doing in your role. They use the beautiful building and promises of free travel to lure people in. Bonus plan is based on last years trend, can be hard to get additional bonus, especially your first year. Bound by meeting specific numbers, minimum number of outbound calls a day, so many hours of talk time on the phone a day. They hire very bubbly and energetic people. People who can hold the attention of an entire room. With very few senior positions, it can be hard to get another job in the company because everyone is competing for the same thing. Very much a popularity contest. Make yourself known and liked on day one. There is large turnover that is never addressed.
reviews.pros: Great first corporate job. They encourage and promote professional development and growth. You learn a lot of skills like time management, public speaking, sales and marketing in the role. The company culture is very young and fun. No dress code, just look semi professional. Everyone tends to be very friendly and easy to talk to. Travel internationally for free at least once a year. You are selling travel to educators, not vacuums door to door. Can be fun if you are passionate about a global education for students. Benefits are great, uncapped sick days, 15 days vacation first year, medical benefits top quality, 401k

reviews.advice:
Give your teachers more money, change the way salaries are increased, work on fixing content not style. There are so many pictures and prompts that are just ridiculous. 
Stop sending so many junk emails about things people already know about and instead only focus on what's important, including a list of admin with their emails.
reviews.cons:
lessons are prepared for you and are terrible for the most part. It's better to ad-lib and some of the topics you're forced to teach! Ish.
It's hard to get to know any one student because their classes are so randomly scheduled. 
You don't really want to have the same student more than once if they give you less that a 5 because they'll continuing ruining your score. 
You can't decline a student if you don't get along with them.
Students are all in the wrong levels and there's no way to fix it as a teacher.
Pay is based on student feedback. 
I don't know who my supervisor was because there would always be new people contacting me about different aspects and there's not really one email that tells you each position and person's name.
The starting pay is really low for what you're doing, even if it is a more "relaxed" job for some than others and it's nearly impossible to increase your pay.
The future direction they're going is TERRIBLE. They're changing platforms from decent to terrible. 
Now you have to look at the student in their house, often times without a shirt on and there's no way to remove their video without asking them to do it nicely. 
It was better when there were absolutely no videos. 
No benefits. At least provide health insurance or something to offset pay.
Despite the globe being 24 hours, the highest peak times to get hours are usually while you should be eating dinner or on the weekends. 
Inconsistent hours, one week it may be 38 and the next 2.
They look at "averages' when they should look at specific cases and specific cases when they should look at averages.
reviews.pros:
Lessons are prepared for you.
Great returning students, when they return.
There are some really, really amazing students at all levels.
Most senior staff responds quickly but a lot of it is just "cut and paste" responses.

reviews.cons:
- No room for career growth unless you are intersted in management (and even then its difficult). Especially if you are located in an office that is not Boston. Go Ahead does not seem to value retention of employees. This is why it is a great job for someone who is just out of college. You can gain experience in an office environment in sales/service, and then take your knowledge somewhere else.
- Hard working, responsible employees tend to be taken advantage of and are not valued as much as they should be. 
- Upper and lower management are not empathetic to every day struggles though they expect their staff to be empathetic constantly. 
- Lots of turnover in the staff and management means constant restructuring and disorganization
- Fairly low pay considering how demanding the work is and how much is expected of you from management



**Recommend to a friend response**: I am adding more depth to this as I do not believe it to be so black and white. I would say "Positive" if you are fresh out of college and/or if are unsure of the direction of your career (or if you need sales/customer service experience). and "Negative" if you have been employed several years out of college and are looking to continue to grow your career.
reviews.pros:
- Great culture. The people who work at EF are what make EF so special. Was able to make a ton of valuable connections cross-office which always helps with future career opportunities. 
- Gained considerable knowledge about sales, customer service, de-escalation, teamwork, travel operations and travel industry knowledge.
- Operations are impressively well run which makes it much easier to sell tours and talk about travel when you believe in the product. I would travel on a tour again even though I am not an employee anymore. 
- Able to travel on a tour once a year. Best perk of them all. 
- Office locations are amazing
- Benefits and time off policy are great. Great healthcare and generous PTO.
reviews.summary: Good place to work if you are young in career

reviews.advice: Invest in your employees, create an environment where employees are encouraged to give feedback and actually take that feedback and do the work to be better.
reviews.cons:
The pay is ridiculously low, goals and compensation structure is horrible and there is no transparency. As a private company EF doesn't disclose any real business statistics. 

Leadership can at times be toxic and unprofessional. 

Diversity- very little diversity and no real efforts to change that. This is particularly sad to see in a company that prides itself in it's international presence. This has been identified as something they want to improve, but it seems to be performative action. The lack of diversity can be seen in their products as well. 

No space to give upward feedback, so management can go unchecked and they get to maintain status quo. 

You will not feel invested in, expect for free lunches here and there and some free beers pre-covid do not expect much else. After more than a year of WFH we never got a stipend for desks, a chair, internet etc. EF has still to even invest in sales tools like Salesforce or Outreach for its sales people. 

Little to no career development or growth, maybe if you ride it out for 3+ years you could be a sales trainer.

Promises of change are touted to keep employees feeling like something good is on the horizon, only to be disappointed when the so-called change is less than expected or worse, non-existent.
reviews.pros:
This was my first sales job and the training program and trainers are amazing! I learned many valuable skills and had the opportunity to do some awesome travel pre-COVID. The mission and product are truly great. 
 
Really fun & young culture and the people are all around amazing!

This is a great job for someone looking to start their sales career, but do not expect to experience any real career development within EF. I was attracted to EF for the possibility of growing my career into a career at one of the many international offices EF has, but that is not something that is ever really talked about.

The skills I gained here opened the door for other higher paying roles.
